alkanes.definitionText: Alkanes are organic acyclic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where all of the carbon–carbon bonds are single.
alkanes.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
alkanes.physicalProperties: First 3 alkanes are gases. Alkanes starting from pentane are liquids. Alkanes starting from C16 are solids. Alkanes are insoluble in water. Alkanes are soluble in organic solvents. Unbranched alkanes have higher boiling points than branched alkanes.

production.1: Hydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons. (t, catalysts: Ni, Pt, Pd):

cycloalkanes.definitionText: Cycloalkanes are organic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where all of the carbon–carbon bonds are single, and the molecule is cyclic.
cycloalkanes.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
cycloalkanes.physicalProperties: Cycloalkanes are gases. Cycloalkanes are insoluble in water. Cycloalkanes are soluble in organic solvents. The boiling points of cycloalkanes increase with the number of carbon atoms in the ring.
cycloalkanes.production: Hydrogenation of alkenes. (t, catalysts: Ni, Pt, Pd):

alkenes.definitionText: Alkenes are organic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where at least one carbon–carbon double bond is present.
alkenes.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
alkenes.isomerism: Branching of the carbon skeleton (see Alkanes)
alkenes.physicalProperties: First 3 alkenes are gases. Alkenes starting from pentene are liquids. Alkenes starting from C18 are solids. Alkenes are slightly soluble in water. Boiling points of unbranched alkenes and cis-isomers are higher, against branched and trans-isomers.

alkynes.definitionText: Alkynes are organic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where at least one carbon–carbon triple bond is present.
alkynes.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
alkynes.isomerism: Branching of the carbon skeleton (see Alkanes)
alkynes.physicalProperties: Like alkenes, the first three alkynes are gases, from C5 to C15 - liquids, from C16 - solids. Slightly soluble in water, density below water. The boiling and melting points of alkynes are higher than those of corresponding alkenes(especially for the first three). Unbranched alkynes have higher boiling points than branched ones.

production.2: Decomposition of calcium carbide with water or acid solution:

arenes.definitionText: Arenes are organic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where at least one carbon–carbon double bond is present.
arenes.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
arenes.physicalProperties: Arenes are gases. Arenes are insoluble in water. Arenes are soluble in organic solvents. The boiling points of arenes increase with the number of carbon atoms in the ring.
arenes.production: Hydrogenation of alkenes. (t, catalysts: Ni, Pt, Pd):

alcohols.definitionText: Alcohols are organic compounds that contain an alcohol functional group, consisting of a hydroxyl group bonded to a carbon atom.
alcohols.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
alcohols.physicalProperties: Lower alcohols are liquids, higher alcohols are solids. The compounds are volatile because hydrogen bonds are weak. The boiling point is higher than that of the corresponding hydrocarbons. They dissolve in water, hydrogen bonds form between the molecules of alcohols and water.

phenols.definitionText: Phenols are hydroxyl derivatives of benzene. They can contain one or several hydroxyl groups in the benzene ring.
phenols.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
phenols.physicalProperties: Phenol is a colorless crystalline substance with a characteristic odor. It turns pink in air. It is poorly soluble in water, but dissolves completely at temperatures above 70°C. It is highly toxic.

aldehydes_ketones.definitionText: Aldehydes and ketones are organic compounds that contain a carbonyl functional group, consisting of a carbon atom double-bonded to an oxygen atom.
aldehydes_ketones.physicalProperties: First 3 alkanes are gases. Alkanes starting from pentane are liquids. Alkanes starting from C16 are solids. Alkanes are insoluble in water. Alkanes are soluble in organic solvents. Unbranched alkanes have higher boiling points than branched alkanes.

ethers.definitionText: Ethers are organic compounds that contain an ether functional group, consisting of two carbon atoms bonded to an oxygen atom.
ethers.physicalProperties: First 3 alkanes are gases. Alkanes starting from pentane are liquids. Alkanes starting from C16 are solids. Alkanes are insoluble in water. Alkanes are soluble in organic solvents. Unbranched alkanes have higher boiling points than branched alkanes.

carboxylicAcids.definitionText: Carboxylic acids are a class of organic compounds whose molecules contain one or more functional carboxyl groups - COOH.
carboxylicAcids.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"
carboxylicAcids.physicalProperties: Saturated straight-chain carboxylic acids containing 1 to 9 carbon atoms, as well as branched ones up to 13 carbon atoms, are liquids, and starting from butyric acid (C4H8O2), they become viscous liquids. Acids containing 1 to 3 carbon atoms have a sharp odor and are miscible with water in any proportions. As the chain grows, their solubility in water decreases. Higher carboxylic acids containing 10 or more carbon atoms are solid substances with no odor and are insoluble in water. Aromatic and dibasic acids are colorless crystalline substances that are readily soluble in water. Their solubility in water, like that of other acids, decreases with increasing carbon chain length.

production.4: Interaction of carboxylic acid salts with mineral acids

esters.definitionText: Esters are derivatives of acids (both organic and inorganic), where the hydrogen atom in the COOH carboxyl group is replaced by a hydrocarbon radical.
esters.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"

isomerism.2: Isomerism of the position of the –CO-O- group:

esters.physicalProperties: Esters of lower carboxylic acids and simple monohydric alcohols are colorless volatile liquids with a characteristic fruity odor. Esters of higher carboxylic acids are colorless solids, insoluble in water. They have a lower boiling point than the corresponding acids.

production.1: The main reaction is the esterification reaction

applications.lubricants: Used as lubricants in the form of natural fats
applications.synthesis: Used in the synthesis of tertiary alcohols

carbohydrates.definitionText: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the ratio of Cn(H2O)n, where n is a positive integer.
carbohydrates.physicalProperties: First 3 alkanes are gases. Alkanes starting from pentane are liquids. Alkanes starting from C16 are solids. Alkanes are insoluble in water. Alkanes are soluble in organic solvents. Unbranched alkanes have higher boiling points than branched alkanes.

amines.definitionText: Amines are organic compounds that contain a nitrogen atom bonded to one or more carbon atoms.
amines.physicalProperties: First 3 alkanes are gases. Alkanes starting from pentane are liquids. Alkanes starting from C16 are solids. Alkanes are insoluble in water. Alkanes are soluble in organic solvents. Unbranched alkanes have higher boiling points than branched alkanes.

amino_acids.definitionText: Amino acids are organic compounds that contain both a carboxyl group (-COOH) and an amino group (-NH2).
amino_acids.physicalProperties: First 3 alkanes are gases. Alkanes starting from pentane are liquids. Alkanes starting from C16 are solids. Alkanes are insoluble in water. Alkanes are soluble in organic solvents. Unbranched alkanes have higher boiling points than branched alkanes.
